Award.AwardTitle: Multi-Scale Modeling of Central Nervous System White Matter

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary objective of this research is to develop a mutli-scale modeling approach based on representative volume elements to enable the accurate depiction and finite element analysis of central nervous system (CNS) white matter, in particular of brain and spinal cord trauma. The vehicle to do this is an integrated multi-disciplinary analytical, computational and experimental methodology consisting of several equally important steps. The underlying hypothesis for the project is that axon fibers are neither firmly tethered nor completely uncoupled to the glial matrix during spinal cord trauma; in fact, they become more tethered with increasing stretch. To this end, microstructural kinematics, omitted by current studies, need to be incorporated to accurately represent and model the white matter of the brain and spinal cord. During the course of this project, we will develop a novel material model for CNS white matter that will capture the micro-scale behavior of axons in a macro-scale continuum analysis. The development of this model will be guided and tested by novel in situ experiments. The major intellectual merit of the proposed work lies upon the computational incorporation of the microstructural axon and glial features and properties into the global (macro) response of the CNS white mater, and the in situ experimental correlation and validation of the simulation data for a variety of loading scenarios. Results from this research will spearhead the development of axon damage tolerance criteria, which is of paramount importance since injury to axons is the proximal cause for loss of function following TBI and SCI. It will also assist in designing new in vivo and in vitro models with the goal of inducing injury in specific patterns and locations based on in silico predictions.

The societal impact lies in that, upon completion, the CNS white mater model will be able to be integrated into analyses of SCI and TBI with more complex loading conditions to predict injury at the single axon level. This is a breakthrough in the CNS biomechanical modeling, which can greatly facilitate diagnostics that can ultimately lead to improved means and measures of injury first response and treatment. The impact of this project in terms of basic research and the spread of knowledge is evident since this multidisciplinary program brings in tasks from materials science, bioengineering, controls, and hi-tech computational techniques, to develop a state of the art tissue diagnostic model, with unique quantitative measuring capabilities and that is described mathematically to its entirety. The educational impact will be significant for our graduate students not only in scientific and engineering fields, but also in mentoring and outreach since they are an integral part of our community efforts through the Rutgers Future Scholars program. Graduate students and undergraduates from minority and under represent groups will be actively recruited. These initiatives provide unique opportunities to these students that will excite them about education and training in engineering and help shape future leaders of our scientific and engineering communities. Finally, in support of results dissemination and outreach, the PI has secured funding to attend the CMMI bi-annual grantees' meeting.

Institution.Name: Rutgers University New Brunswick
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

POR.DRECONTENT:
Brain’s white matter is composed of multiple microstructures that synergistically build up to it’s functionality. Damage occurring in the brain initiates at the microstructural level, see neurons, and propagates to large scales, for example corpus collosum, where it can be detected by current imaging techniques like MRI. The motivation of the proposed investigation is the lack of a multiscale description of white matter that would facilitate the identification of the cascade effects that cause axonal damage during a traumatic brain injury incident.

Building models of white matter mechanical response from accurate kinematic descriptions is crucial for understanding tissue mechanics during trauma for two reasons.  First, from a micro-to-macro perspective, the kinematic coupling among axons strongly influences the tissue-level mechanical properties, with affine microkinematic behavior generally resulting in stiffer material response at the macro-scale. Second, from a macro-to-micro perspective, the microkinematic behavior dictates the response of individual axons to tissue-level mechanical loading.

Intellectual Merit

In the course of this study a virtual representation of the axonal microstructure of the central nervous system in the white matter was generated.  A method enabling neuron undulation was developed, increasing the model similarity to real-life geometries and significantly distinguishing it from previous research in microscale biomechanical modeling. Furthermore, the strain-dependent composite behavior of neurons into a continuum kinematics-based model of white matter was adopted ensuing the scalability of the simulations from the micro-scale, see neurons, to higher scales observable by imaging techniques. Finally, the resulting white matter representative volume element was subjected to external loads simulating the conditions of mild trauma and the ensuing effective properties were calculated.  The properties were then successfully compared to stress-strain profiles from chick embryo spinal cord and guinea pig optic nerve data in order to validate the model. Future work entails correlations and comparisons of the model with human brain tissue and MRI images. The innovativeness of the performed work lies in the accurate representation of the axonal micro architecture in different regions of the white matter and the potential capability to account mechanical damage sequelae though multiple scales.

Broader Impact

Current material models mathematical simulations of the central nervous system’s soft tissues are largely based on phenomenological assumptions.  Building models of white matter behavior from accurate biomechanical descriptions is crucial for understanding tissue mechanics during trauma. Since tensile stretch has been demonstrated to be the best predictor of structural and functional injury to individual axons following trauma, injury can only be accurately predicted when the coupling behavior of the resident axons is described. A pure affine description implies that stretch experienced by a single axon follows tissue level stretch exactly, whereas a non-affine description implies that the slack present in an undulated axon is first taken up prior to the axon experiencing stretch. It is known that axons within a population in white matter are undulated to different degrees, and that the kinematic behavior is dependent on the level of stretch.

As such, to truly predict how axons are injured during traumatic brain injury (TBI) or spinal cord injury (SCI), a mathematical description of axon undulation and kinematic coupling mimicking the neuronal architecture is necessary. To this end, the major accomplishment of this work is the accurate mechanical representation of the microstructure of the white matter in terms of the axon/glia composite system.  The deve...

The motivation of the proposed investigation is the lack of a multiscale description of white matter that would facilitate the identification of the cascade effects that cause axonal damage during a traumatic brain injury incident. Building models of white matter mechanical response from accurate kinematic descriptions is crucial for understanding tissue mechanics during trauma for two reasons. Second, from a macro-to-micro perspective, the microkinematic behavior dictates the response of individual axons to tissue-level mechanical loading. A method enabling neuron undulation was developed, increasing the model similarity to real-life geometries and significantly distinguishing it from previous research in microscale biomechanical modeling. The properties were then successfully compared to stress-strain profiles from chick embryo spinal cord and guinea pig optic nerve data in order to validate the model. Future work entails correlations and comparisons of the model with human brain tissue and MRI images. The innovativeness of the performed work lies in the accurate representation of the axonal micro architecture in different regions of the white matter and the potential capability to account mechanical damage sequelae though multiple scales. Broader Impact Current material models mathematical simulations of the central nervous systemÆs soft tissues are largely based on phenomenological assumptions. Building models of white matter behavior from accurate biomechanical descriptions is crucial for understanding tissue mechanics during trauma. Since tensile stretch has been demonstrated to be the best predictor of structural and functional injury to individual axons following trauma, injury can only be accurately predicted when the coupling behavior of the resident axons is described. A pure affine description implies that stretch experienced by a single axon follows tissue level stretch exactly, whereas a non-affine description implies that the slack present in an undulated axon is first taken up prior to the axon experiencing stretch. It is known that axons within a population in white matter are undulated to different degrees, and that the kinematic behavior is dependent on the level of stretch. As such, to truly predict how axons are injured during traumatic brain injury (TBI) or spinal cord injury (SCI), a mathematical description of axon undulation and kinematic coupling mimicking the neuronal architecture is necessary. To this end, the major accomplishment of this work is the accurate mechanical representation of the microstructure of the white matter in terms of the axon/glia composite system.
